Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Algorithmic and Quantitative Semi-Algebraic Geometry and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Algorithmic semi-algebraic geometry lies at the heart of many problems in several different areas of computer science and mathematics, including discrete and computational geometry, robot motion planning, geometric modeling, computer-aided design, geometric theorem proving, mathematical investigations of real algebraic varieties, molecular chemistry, constraint databases, etc.

Recent breakthroughs in discrete and computational geometry have spurred new research in real algebraic geometry, and there is a new synergy between these two fields. The award funds research that contributes to both areas -- increasing our understanding of real algebraic geometry, and how it impacts discrete and computational geometry. The main new ideas involved include more intricate perturbation schemes of polynomials using infinitesimals, and novel application of the well developed tool from differential topology -- namely, Morse theory, including stratified Morse theory, used in the context of semi-algebraic geometry. The results will potentially have far reaching impact in the study of arrangements in computational geometry, computer graphics, robotics, and even in areas of pure mathematics such as harmonic analysis. In addition, the research aims at developing newer and more efficient algorithms for several extremely important problems in algorithmic semi-algebraic geometry. These include algorithms for computing "roadmaps", a crucial ingredient in deciding questions of connectivity of semi-algebraic sets. These improvements will potentially impact the way the vitally important problem of robot motion planning is dealt with currently.

All these research objectives are integrated in a broad program of training graduate students and curriculum development. In particular, graduate students are involved in both aspects -- namely, proving theoretical results, as well as practical implementations of algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this project was to develop new algorithms for computing certain topological invariants of semi-algebraic sets, and obtain new quantitative results on the topological complexity of semi-algebraic sets keeping in mind the needs of more precise results in this direction coming from the new developments in the area of incidence geometry. These goals have been met.

New nearly optimal algorithms for computing "roadmaps" of real algebraic sets (and hence information regarding their connectivity), as well algorithms for computing more sophisticated topological invariants (such as the Euler-Poincare characteristics) for symmetric semi-algebraic sets were developed.More precisely, in a joint work with M-F. Roy, a deterministic divide and conquer algorithm was given for the problem of computing a roadmap of a real variety defined by a polynomial of degree d in n variables. The complexity of the algorithm is  nlog n dO(n log2n)   which is close to optimal, and nearly matches the complexity of the most efficient deterministic algorithm for deciding whether such a variety is empty. This resolves almost completely an open question in the field of algorithmic semi-algebraic geometry, that has been open for over twenty years. In addition, with C. Riener, new algorithms were developed with polynomially bounded complexity for computing the Euler-Poincare characteristics of semi-algebraic sets defined by symmetric polynomials of fixed degrees. This is particularly striking,  since the best known algorithm in the non-symmetric situation for the same problem has complexity which is singly exponential in the number of variables (and this cannot be improved unless P=NP). 

On the quantitative side, newer and much more refined estimates (compared to previously existing results) on the number of connected components, as well as the sum of the Betti numbers, of real varieties and semi-algebraic sets were obtained (in joint work with S. Barone and separately with A. Rizzie). The main contribution for the first part of this work was a somewhat intricate construction of certain varieties which "approximated" the given possibly highly singular variety. These approximating varieties additionally have nice algebraic properties, being non-singular complete intersections, and the degrees of the polynomials defining them are carefully controlled in terms of the degrees of the polynomials defining the given variety.  As a result, a real analog of the Bezout inquality (which need not hold for non-transversal intersections of real varieties) was obtained. These results have already found applications in works of other researchers in incidence geometry and elsewhere. A direct application of these results resulted in a new method for performing multi-level polynomial partitioning (a very active area of research in discrete and computational geometry),  which was then used to prove a new incidence result between points and hypersurfaces in R4 (joint work with M. Sombra). 

In joint work with C. Riener, semi-algebraic sets defined by symmetric polynomials of small (fixed) degrees were studied from representation-theoretic as well as topological perspective. Quantitative bounds, which are polynomial in the number of variables were obtained on the multiplicities of various irreducible representations of the symmetric group occurring in the isotypic  decomposition of the cohomology modules of such sets.  Thus, while the cohomology spaces of such sets can have exponentially large dimensions, they can be encoded using a polynomial amount of data -- namely, the multiplicties and the partitions labelling the various irreducible representations of the symmetric group. These are the very first results in this direction which looks like a very promising area of research, and several open problems, both of algorithmic and quantitative nature have been identified for future studies.

Finally, a foundation of the study of effective algorithms and complexity were laid in the context of constructible sheaves in the semi-algebraic category. Complexity classes were defined for sequences of constructible functions and sheaves. A classical result of Kashiwara and Schapira on the constructivity of the direct image sheaf of a constructible sheaf was made effective with singly exponential upper bounds on the complexity. This is a sheaf theoretic generalization of effective quantifier elimination in the theory of the reals. For constructible functions, the new classes are a real analog (in the style of Blum, Shub and Smale) of complexity classes of counting functions defined by Valiant in discrete complexity theory. Applications would include developing a theory of complexity in the theory of D-modules, generalized functions etc. where constructible sheaves play an important role.

Aside from the applications already mentioned, the results obtained during this project have the potential to have an impact on diverse fields -- including discrete and computational geometry, computational complexity theory, motion planning in robotics,  amongst others. Several graduate students were trained and the results disseminated via talks at conferences and two survey articles.
